title: 108_hr3688
content: The Act titled "Integrity of the United States Courts Act of 2003" allows for judicial review of binational panel and committee decisions under the North American Free Trade Agreement Implementation Act. The "Integrity of the United States Courts Act of 2003" permits judicial review of binational panel and committee determinations under the North American Free Trade Agreement Implementation Act within 30 days of publication in the Federal Register. If a Party or person alleges misinterpretation of U.S. law, misconduct, bias, conflict of interest, or rule violations by panel or committee members, they can seek review in the Court of International Trade. If a party or person believes that a binational panel or committee has seriously departed from procedure or exceeded its powers, they can appeal to the United States Court of International Trade for review. This is allowed under the "Integrity of the United States Courts Act of 2003" for disputes under the North American Free Trade Agreement Implementation Act. If a binational panel or committee does not act within 120 days after a request for review under article 1904, a person can contest the determination by commencing an action in the United States Court of International Trade. This is allowed under the "Integrity of the United States Courts Act of 2003" for disputes under the North American Free Trade Agreement Implementation Act. After a binational panel or committee fails to act within 120 days, a person can challenge the decision by filing an action in the United States Court of International Trade under the "Integrity of the United States Courts Act of 2003" for disputes related to the North American Free Trade Agreement Implementation Act. Other individuals can also initiate actions within 30 days of the initial filing, limited to claims raised before the panel or committee. The Court of International Trade reviews appeals of panel decisions, examining the legal and factual analysis underlying the findings. The Court of International Trade reviews appeals of panel decisions under the "Integrity of the United States Courts Act of 2003" for disputes related to the North American Free Trade Agreement Implementation Act. If any elements described in subsection (a)(1)(A) are established, the court vacates the original decision and enters judgment accordingly. Decisions of the Court of International Trade are binding on the parties regarding the matters before the panel. The Court of International Trade has exclusive jurisdiction over appeals related to the North American Free Trade Agreement Implementation Act. Decisions made by the Court are binding on all parties involved. This section applies to determinations by a binational panel or committee under NAFTA regarding antidumping or countervailing duty determinations in the US. SEC. 3. JURISDICTION OF THE COURT OF INTERNATIONAL TRADE. Section 516A of the Tariff Act of 1930 is amended to include final determinations of binational panels under NAFTA and the North American Free Trade Agreement Implementation Act. The Tariff Act of 1930 is amended to include final determinations of binational panels under NAFTA and the North American Free Trade Agreement Implementation Act, including a new provision for review requests under section 404A. The amendments made by this Act apply to goods from Canada and Mexico under the North American Free Trade Agreement. The effective date includes final determinations of binational panels under NAFTA and review requests under section 404A.
